Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade

_**Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade**_ is a 1989 American
[action](/wiki/Action_film "Action film")-[adventure
film](/wiki/Adventure_film "Adventure film") directed by [Steven
Spielberg](/wiki/Steven_Spielberg "Steven Spielberg"), from a story co-written
by executive producer [George Lucas](/wiki/George_Lucas "George Lucas"). It is
the third installment in the [_Indiana Jones_
franchise](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_\(franchise\) "Indiana Jones \(franchise\)").
[Harrison Ford](/wiki/Harrison_Ford "Harrison Ford") reprises [the title
role](/wiki/Indiana_Jones "Indiana Jones") and [Sean
Connery](/wiki/Sean_Connery "Sean Connery") plays Indiana's father, [Henry
Jones, Sr.](/wiki/Henry_Jones,_Sr. "Henry Jones, Sr.") Other cast members
featured include [Alison Doody](/wiki/Alison_Doody "Alison Doody"), [Denholm
Elliott](/wiki/Denholm_Elliott "Denholm Elliott"), [Julian
Glover](/wiki/Julian_Glover "Julian Glover"), [River
Phoenix](/wiki/River_Phoenix "River Phoenix"), and [John Rhys-
Davies](/wiki/John_Rhys-Davies "John Rhys-Davies"). In the film, set largely
in 1938, Indiana searches for his father, a [Holy Grail](/wiki/Holy_Grail
"Holy Grail") scholar, who has been kidnapped by [Nazis](/wiki/Nazi_Germany
"Nazi Germany").

After the mixed reaction to _[Indiana Jones and the Temple of
Doom](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Temple_of_Doom "Indiana Jones and the Temple
of Doom")_ , Spielberg chose to compensate with a film that toned down the
violence and gore. During the five years between _Temple of Doom_ and _Last
Crusade_ , he and executive producer Lucas reviewed several scripts before
accepting [Jeffrey Boam](/wiki/Jeffrey_Boam "Jeffrey Boam")'s. Filming
locations included [Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain"), [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy"),
the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"),
[Turkey](/wiki/Turkey "Turkey") and [Jordan](/wiki/Jordan "Jordan").

The film was released in North America on May 24, 1989 to mostly positive
reviews and a financial success, earning $474.2 million at the worldwide box
office totals. It won an [Academy Award](/wiki/Academy_Award "Academy Award")
for [Best Sound Editing](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Sound_Editing "Academy
Award for Best Sound Editing").

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

In 1912, thirteen-year-old [Indiana Jones](/wiki/Indiana_Jones "Indiana
Jones") is horseback riding with his [Boy Scout](/wiki/Boy_Scouts_of_America
"Boy Scouts of America") troop at [Arches National
Park](/wiki/Arches_National_Park "Arches National Park") in [Utah](/wiki/Utah
"Utah"). While scouting caves, Indy discovers a group of grave robbers who
have found a golden [crucifix](/wiki/Crucifix "Crucifix") belonging to
[Coronado](/wiki/Francisco_V%C3%A1squez_de_Coronado "Francisco Vásquez de
Coronado") and steals it from them, hoping to donate it to a museum. The men
give chase through a passing [circus train](/wiki/Circus_train "Circus
train"), leaving Indy with a bloody cut across his chin from a
[bullwhip](/wiki/Bullwhip "Bullwhip") and a new [phobia of
snakes](/wiki/Ophidiophobia "Ophidiophobia"). Indy escapes, but the local
sheriff makes him return the cross to the robbers. Impressed with Indy's
bravery, the leader of the robbers gives Indy his [fedora](/wiki/Fedora
"Fedora"), and encourages him to not give up.

In 1938, Indy recovers the cross off the coast of
[Portugal](/wiki/Estado_Novo_\(Portugal\) "Estado Novo \(Portugal\)") and
donates it to [Marcus Brody](/wiki/Marcus_Brody "Marcus Brody")'s museum.
Later, Indy is introduced to [Walter Donovan](/wiki/Walter_Donovan "Walter
Donovan"), who informs him that Indy's father, [Henry Jones
Sr.](/wiki/Henry_Jones_Sr. "Henry Jones Sr."), has vanished while searching
for the [Holy Grail](/wiki/Holy_Grail "Holy Grail"), using an incomplete
inscription as his guide. Indy then receives Henry's Grail diary via mail from
[Venice](/wiki/Venice "Venice"). Realizing that he would not have sent the
diary unless he was in trouble, Indy and Marcus travel to Venice, where they
meet Henry's [Austrian](/wiki/Federal_State_of_Austria "Federal State of
Austria") colleague, Dr. [Elsa Schneider](/wiki/Elsa_Schneider "Elsa
Schneider"). Beneath the library where Henry was last seen, Indy and Elsa
discover the tomb of a [First Crusade](/wiki/First_Crusade "First Crusade")
knight, which also contains a complete version of the inscription that Henry
had used, this one revealing the location of the Grail. They flee, however,
when the catacombs are set aflame by the Brotherhood of the Cruciform Sword, a
[secret society](/wiki/Secret_society "Secret society") that protects the
Grail from evildoers. Indy and Elsa capture one of the Brotherhood,
[Kazim](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_the_Indiana_Jones_series#Kazim "List of
characters in the Indiana Jones series"), and Indy tells him that his goal is
only to find his father and that he has no interest in finding the Grail.
Kazim tells him that Henry is being held in Castle Brunwald on the Austrian-
German border. Marcus later reveals a map drawn by Henry of the route to the
Grail, which begins in [Alexandretta](/wiki/%C4%B0skenderun "İskenderun").
Indy removes the pages containing the map from the diary, gives it to Marcus
for safekeeping and sends Marcus to İskenderun, the city built on the ruins of
Alexandretta to rendezvous with their old friend [Sallah](/wiki/Sallah
"Sallah"), and he and Elsa head to Castle Brunwald.

At Castle Brunwald, Indy rescues Henry, but learns that Elsa and Donovan are
actually working with the [Nazis](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany"), and are
using him to find the Grail for them. Meanwhile, Marcus is captured in
[Hatay](/wiki/Hatay_State "Hatay State"), while waiting with
[Sallah](/wiki/Sallah "Sallah") for the Joneses. The Joneses escape from
Castle Brunwald. Henry tells Indy that to reach the Grail, one must face three
[booby traps](/wiki/Booby_trap "Booby trap") and his diary contains the clues
to guide them through the challenges safely. They recover the diary from Elsa
at a [book burning](/wiki/Nazi_book_burnings "Nazi book burnings") rally in
[Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin"). They then board a [Zeppelin](/wiki/Zeppelin
"Zeppelin") to leave Germany, but the Nazis soon discover the Joneses are
aboard and they escape in a [parasite](/wiki/Parasite_aircraft "Parasite
aircraft") [biplane](/wiki/Biplane "Biplane"). They crash while engaging in a
[dogfight](/wiki/Dogfight "Dogfight") with [Luftwaffe](/wiki/Luftwaffe
"Luftwaffe") fighters.

The two meet up with Sallah in Hatay, where they learn of Marcus's abduction.
The Nazis are already moving toward the Grail's location, using the map
possessed by Marcus. In exchange for a [Rolls-Royce](/wiki/Rolls-
Royce_Phantom_II "Rolls-Royce Phantom II"), the [Sultan](/wiki/Sultan
"Sultan") of Hatay has given the Nazis full access to his equipment for the
expedition, including a large tank. Indy, Henry, and Sallah find the Nazi
expedition, which is ambushed by the Brotherhood. During the battle, Henry is
captured by SS Colonel [Ernst
Vogel](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_the_Indiana_Jones_series#Vogel "List of
characters in the Indiana Jones series") while attempting to rescue Marcus
from the tank; Kazim and his comrades are killed. The younger Jones pursues
the tank on horseback and, with the aid of Sallah, saves Henry and Marcus. He
is then caught up in a fight with Vogel, and barely escapes before the tank
goes over a cliff, crushing Vogel to death.

Indy, Henry, Marcus, and Sallah catch up with the surviving Nazis, led by
Donovan and Elsa, who have found the temple where the Grail is kept but are
unable to pass through the three protective booby traps. Donovan mortally
wounds Henry in order to force Indy to risk his life in the traps to find the
Grail and use its healing power to save Henry. Using the information in the
diary and followed by Donovan and Elsa, Indy safely overcomes the traps and
reaches the Grail's chamber, which is guarded by a knight. He has been kept
alive for seven hundred years by the power of the Grail, which is hidden among
dozens of false Grails; only the true Grail brings life, while a false one
claims it. Elsa purposefully selects the most princely grail, a golden chalice
studded with emeralds, for Donovan, who ages into dust after drinking from it,
because the one Elsa chose was a false one. Indy selects the true Grail, a
simple wooden cup, which the knight warns cannot be taken beyond the temple's
entrance. Indy fills the Grail with [holy water](/wiki/Holy_water "Holy
water") and takes it to Henry, which heals him instantly. Elsa, disregarding
the knight's warning, then takes the Grail and attempts to leave with it. The
temple begins to collapse and Elsa falls to her death trying to recover the
Grail. Indy nearly suffers the same fate but Henry persuades him to let it go.
The Joneses, Marcus, and Sallah escape the temple and ride off into the
sunset.

##
Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast")]

See also: [List of characters in the Indiana Jones
series](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_the_Indiana_Jones_series "List of
characters in the Indiana Jones series")

  * [Harrison Ford](/wiki/Harrison_Ford "Harrison Ford") as [Indiana Jones](/wiki/Indiana_Jones "Indiana Jones"): The archaeologist adventurer who seeks to rescue his father and find the Holy Grail. Ford said he loved the idea of introducing Indiana's father because it allowed him to explore another side to Indiana's personality: "These are men who have never made any accommodation to each other. Indy behaves differently in his father's presence. Who else would dare call Indy 'junior'?"[3]
    * [River Phoenix](/wiki/River_Phoenix "River Phoenix") as the teenage Jones. Phoenix had portrayed the son of Ford's character in _[The Mosquito Coast](/wiki/The_Mosquito_Coast "The Mosquito Coast")_ (1986). Ford recommended Phoenix for the part; he said that of the young actors working at the time, Phoenix looked the most like him when he was around that age.[4]
  * [Sean Connery](/wiki/Sean_Connery "Sean Connery") as [Professor Henry Jones](/wiki/Henry_Jones,_Sr. "Henry Jones, Sr."): Indiana's father, a professor of [Medieval literature](/wiki/Medieval_literature "Medieval literature") who cared more about looking for the Grail than raising his son. Spielberg had Connery in mind when he suggested introducing Indiana's father, though he did not tell Lucas at first. Consequently, Lucas wrote the role as "a crazy, eccentric" professor resembling [Laurence Olivier](/wiki/Laurence_Olivier "Laurence Olivier"), whose relationship with Indiana is "strict schoolmaster and student rather than a father and son".[5] Spielberg had been a fan of Connery's work as [James Bond](/wiki/James_Bond_\(character\) "James Bond \(character\)") and felt that no one else could perform the role as well.[6] Spielberg biographer [Joseph McBride](/wiki/Joseph_McBride_\(writer\) "Joseph McBride \(writer\)") wrote, "Connery was already the father of Indiana Jones since the series had sprung from the desire of Lucas and Spielberg to rival (and outdo) Connery's [_James Bond_ movies](/wiki/James_Bond_\(film_series\) "James Bond \(film series\)")."[7] Connery initially turned the role down as he is only twelve years older than Ford, but he relented. Connery—a student of history—began to reshape the character, and revisions were made to the script to address his concerns. "I wanted to play Henry Jones as a kind of [Sir Richard [Francis] Burton](/wiki/Richard_Francis_Burton "Richard Francis Burton")," Connery commented. "I was bound to have fun with the role of a gruff, Victorian Scottish father."[6] Connery believed Henry should be a match for his son, telling Spielberg that "whatever Indy'd done my character has done and my character has done it better".[4] Connery signed to the film on March 25, 1988.[5] He improvised the line, "She talks in her sleep", which was left in because it made everyone laugh;[8] in Boam's scripts, Henry telling Indiana that he slept with Elsa occurs later.[5]
    * [Alex Hyde-White](/wiki/Alex_Hyde-White "Alex Hyde-White") as Young Henry Jones, Sr.
  * [Alison Doody](/wiki/Alison_Doody "Alison Doody") as [Dr. Elsa Schneider](/wiki/Dr._Elsa_Schneider "Dr. Elsa Schneider"): An Austrian art professor who is in league with the Nazis. She seduces the Joneses to trick them. Doody was 21 when she auditioned and was one of the first actresses who met for the part.[5]
  * [Denholm Elliott](/wiki/Denholm_Elliott "Denholm Elliott") as Dr. Marcus Brody: Indiana's bumbling English colleague. Elliott returned after Spielberg sought to recapture the tone of _[Raiders of the Lost Ark](/wiki/Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark "Raiders of the Lost Ark")_ (1981), following the actor's absence in the darker _[Temple of Doom](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Temple_of_Doom "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom")_ (1984).[4]
  * [John Rhys-Davies](/wiki/John_Rhys-Davies "John Rhys-Davies") as [Sallah](/wiki/Sallah "Sallah"): A friend of Indiana and a professional [excavator](/wiki/Excavation_\(archaeology\) "Excavation \(archaeology\)") living in [Cairo](/wiki/Cairo "Cairo"). Like Elliott's, Rhys-Davies' return was an attempt to recapture the spirit of _Raiders of the Lost Ark_.[4]
  * [Julian Glover](/wiki/Julian_Glover "Julian Glover") as Walter Donovan: An American businessman who sends the Joneses on their quest for the Holy Grail. Donovan works for the Nazis and desires [immortality](/wiki/Immortality "Immortality"). Glover previously appeared as [General Veers](/wiki/List_of_Star_Wars_characters#V "List of Star Wars characters") in Lucas's _[The Empire Strikes Back](/wiki/The_Empire_Strikes_Back "The Empire Strikes Back")_. He originally auditioned for the role of Vogel. Glover, who is English, adopted an American accent for the film,[9] but was dissatisfied with the result.[4]
  * [Michael Byrne](/wiki/Michael_Byrne_\(actor\) "Michael Byrne \(actor\)") as [Colonel](/wiki/Standartenf%C3%BChrer "Standartenführer") Vogel: A brutal [SS](/wiki/Schutzstaffel "Schutzstaffel") colonel. Byrne and Ford had previously starred in _[Force 10 from Navarone](/wiki/Force_10_from_Navarone_\(film\) "Force 10 from Navarone \(film\)")_ (1978), in which they also respectively played a German and an American.[10]
  * [Kevork Malikyan](/wiki/Kevork_Malikyan "Kevork Malikyan") as Kazim: The leader of the Brotherhood of the Cruciform Sword, an organization that protects the Holy Grail. Malikyan had impressed Spielberg with his performance in _[Midnight Express](/wiki/Midnight_Express_\(film\) "Midnight Express \(film\)")_ (1978) and would have auditioned for the role of Sallah in _Raiders of the Lost Ark_ had a traffic jam not delayed his meeting with the director.[10]
  * [Robert Eddison](/wiki/Robert_Eddison "Robert Eddison") as the Grail Knight: The guardian of the Grail who drank from the cup of Christ during the Crusades and is immortal as long as he stays within the temple. Eddison was a stage and television veteran only appearing once before in film (a supporting role in Peter Ustinov's 1948 comedy _[Vice Versa)](/wiki/Vice_Versa_\(1948_film\) "Vice Versa \(1948 film\)")_. Glover recalled Eddison was excited and nervous for his film debut, often asking if he had performed correctly.[11] [Laurence Olivier](/wiki/Laurence_Olivier "Laurence Olivier") was originally considered to play the Grail Knight,[12] but he was too ill and died the same year in which the film was released.

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

###
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Development")]

Lucas and Spielberg had intended to make a trilogy of _[Indiana
Jones](/wiki/Indiana_Jones "Indiana Jones")_ films since Lucas had first
[pitched](/wiki/Pitch_\(filmmaking\) "Pitch \(filmmaking\)") _[Raiders of the
Lost Ark](/wiki/Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark "Raiders of the Lost Ark")_ to
Spielberg in 1977.[13] After the mixed critical and public reaction to
_[Indiana Jones and the Temple of
Doom](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Temple_of_Doom "Indiana Jones and the Temple
of Doom")_ , Spielberg decided to complete the trilogy to fulfill his promise
to Lucas and "to apologize for the second one".[14] The pair had the intention
of revitalizing the series by evoking the spirit and tone of _Raiders of the
Lost Ark_.[4] Throughout the film's development and [pre-
production](/wiki/Pre-production "Pre-production"), Spielberg admitted he was
"consciously regressing" in making the film.[7] Due to his commitment to the
film, the director had to drop out of directing _[Big](/wiki/Big_\(film\) "Big
\(film\)")_ and _[Rain Man](/wiki/Rain_Man "Rain Man")_.[13]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Xiyou.PNG/170px-
Xiyou.PNG)](/wiki/File:Xiyou.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:Xiyou.PNG "Enlarge")

Chris Columbus' script featured the Monkey King in Africa

Lucas initially suggested making the film "a [haunted
mansion](/wiki/Haunted_house "Haunted house") movie", for which _[Romancing
the Stone](/wiki/Romancing_the_Stone "Romancing the Stone")_ writer [Diane
Thomas](/wiki/Diane_Thomas "Diane Thomas") wrote a script. Spielberg rejected
the idea because of the similarity to
_[Poltergeist](/wiki/Poltergeist_\(1982_film\) "Poltergeist \(1982 film\)")_ ,
which he had co-written and produced.[7] Lucas first introduced the [Holy
Grail](/wiki/Holy_Grail "Holy Grail") in an idea for the film's prologue,
which was to be set in Scotland. He intended the Grail to have a
[pagan](/wiki/Pagan "Pagan") basis, with the rest of the film revolving around
a separate Christian artifact in Africa. Spielberg did not care for the Grail
idea, which he found too [esoteric](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/esoteric
"wikt:esoteric"),[3] even after Lucas suggested giving it healing powers and
the ability to grant immortality. In September 1984, Lucas completed an eight-
page treatment titled _Indiana Jones and the[Monkey King](/wiki/Sun_Wukong
"Sun Wukong")_, which he soon followed with an 11-page outline. The story saw
Indiana battling a ghost in Scotland before finding the [Fountain of
Youth](/wiki/Fountain_of_Youth "Fountain of Youth") in Africa.[5]

[Chris Columbus](/wiki/Chris_Columbus_\(filmmaker\) "Chris Columbus
\(filmmaker\)")—who had written the Spielberg-produced
_[Gremlins](/wiki/Gremlins "Gremlins")_ , _[The Goonies](/wiki/The_Goonies
"The Goonies")_ , and _[Young Sherlock Holmes](/wiki/Young_Sherlock_Holmes
"Young Sherlock Holmes")_ —was hired to write the script. His first draft,
dated May 3, 1985, changed the main plot device to a Garden of Immortal
Peaches. It begins in 1937, with Indiana battling the murderous ghost of Baron
Seamus Seagrove III in Scotland. Indiana travels to
[Mozambique](/wiki/Mozambique "Mozambique") to aid Dr. Clare Clarke (a
[Katharine Hepburn](/wiki/Katharine_Hepburn "Katharine Hepburn") type
according to Lucas), who has found a 200-year-old [pygmy](/wiki/Pygmies
"Pygmies"). The pygmy is kidnapped by the Nazis during a boat chase, and
Indiana, Clare and Scraggy Brier—an old friend of Indiana—travel up the
[Zambezi](/wiki/Zambezi "Zambezi") river to rescue him. Indiana is killed in
the climactic battle but is resurrected by the Monkey King. Other characters
include a cannibalistic African tribe; Nazi Sergeant Gutterbuhg, who has a
mechanical arm; Betsy, a stowaway student who is suicidally in love with
Indiana; and a pirate leader named Kezure (described as a [Toshiro
Mifune](/wiki/Toshiro_Mifune "Toshiro Mifune") type), who dies eating a peach
because he is not pure of heart.[5]

Columbus's second draft, dated August 6, 1985, removed Betsy and featured
Dash—an [expatriate](/wiki/Expatriate "Expatriate") bar owner for whom the
Nazis work—and the Monkey King as villains. The Monkey King forces Indiana and
Dash to play chess with real people and disintegrates each person who is
[captured](/wiki/Capture_\(chess\) "Capture \(chess\)"). Indiana subsequently
battles the undead, destroys the Monkey King's rod, and marries Clare.[5]
[Location scouting](/wiki/Location_scouting "Location scouting") commenced in
Africa but Spielberg and Lucas abandoned _Monkey King_ because of its negative
depiction of African natives,[15] and because the script was too
unrealistic.[5] Spielberg acknowledged that it made him "... feel very old,
too old to direct it."[3] Columbus's script was leaked onto the Internet in
1997, and many believed it was an early draft for [the fourth
film](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Kingdom_of_the_Crystal_Skull "Indiana Jones
and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull") because it was mistakenly dated to
1995.[16]

Unsatisfied, Spielberg suggested introducing Indiana's father, [Henry Jones,
Sr.](/wiki/Henry_Jones,_Sr. "Henry Jones, Sr.") Lucas was dubious, believing
the Grail should be the story's focus, but Spielberg convinced him that the
father–son relationship would serve as a great metaphor in Indiana's search
for the artifact.[7] Spielberg hired [Menno Meyjes](/wiki/Menno_Meyjes "Menno
Meyjes"), who had worked on Spielberg's _[The Color
Purple](/wiki/The_Color_Purple_\(1985_film\) "The Color Purple \(1985
film\)")_ and _[Empire of the Sun](/wiki/Empire_of_the_Sun_\(film\) "Empire of
the Sun \(film\)")_ , to begin a new script on January 1, 1986. Meyjes
completed his script ten months later. It depicted Indiana searching for his
father in [Montségur](/wiki/Monts%C3%A9gur "Montségur"), where he meets a nun
named Chantal. Indiana travels to [Venice](/wiki/Venice "Venice"), takes the
_[Orient Express](/wiki/Orient_Express "Orient Express")_ to
[Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul"), and continues by train to
[Petra](/wiki/Petra "Petra"), where he meets [Sallah](/wiki/Sallah "Sallah")
and reunites with his father. Together they find the grail. At the climax, a
Nazi villain touches the Grail and explodes; when Henry touches it, he ascends
a stairway to [Heaven](/wiki/Heaven "Heaven"). Chantal chooses to stay on
Earth because of her love for Indiana. In a revised draft dated two months
later, Indiana finds his father in [Krak des
Chevaliers](/wiki/Krak_des_Chevaliers "Krak des Chevaliers"), the Nazi leader
is a woman named Greta von Grimm, and Indiana battles a demon at the Grail
site, which he defeats with a dagger inscribed with "God is King". The
prologue in both drafts has Indiana in Mexico battling for possession of
[Montezuma](/wiki/Moctezuma_II "Moctezuma II")'s death mask with a man who
owns gorillas as pets.[5]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Cross_of_Coronado.jpg/220px-
Indiana_Jones_and_the_Cross_of_Coronado.jpg)](/wiki/File:Indiana_Jones_and_the_Cross_of_Coronado.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Indiana_Jones_and_the_Cross_of_Coronado.jpg "Enlarge")

[Indiana Jones](/wiki/Indiana_Jones "Indiana Jones") ([River
Phoenix](/wiki/River_Phoenix "River Phoenix")) finds the Cross of Coronado as
a 13-year-old Boy Scout. Spielberg suggested making Indiana a Boy Scout as
both he and Harrison Ford were former Scouts.

Spielberg suggested _[Innerspace](/wiki/Innerspace "Innerspace")_ writer
[Jeffrey Boam](/wiki/Jeffrey_Boam "Jeffrey Boam") perform the next rewrite.
Boam spent two weeks reworking the story with Lucas, which yielded a treatment
that is largely similar to the final film.[5] Boam told Lucas that Indiana
should find his father in the middle of the story. "Given the fact that it's
the third film in the series, you couldn't just end with them obtaining the
object. That's how the first two films ended," he said, "So I thought, let
them _lose_ the Grail, and let the father–son relationship be the main point.
It's an archaeological search for Indy's own identity and coming to accept his
father is more what it's about [than the quest for the Grail]."[7] Boam said
he felt there was not enough character development in the previous films.[3]
In Boam's first draft, dated September 1987, the film is set in 1939. The
prologue has adult Indiana retrieving an Aztec relic for a museum curator in
Mexico and features the circus train. Henry and Elsa (who is described as
having dark hair) were searching for the Grail on behalf of the Chandler
Foundation, before Henry went missing. The character of Kazim is here named
Kemal, and is an agent of the Republic of Hatay, which seeks the grail for its
own. Kemal shoots Henry and dies drinking from the wrong chalice. The Grail
Knight battles Indiana on horseback, while Vogel is crushed by a boulder when
stealing the Grail.[5]

Boam's February 23, 1988 rewrite utilized many of Connery's comic suggestions.
It included the prologue that was eventually filmed; Lucas had to convince
Spielberg to show Indiana as a boy because of the mixed response to _Empire of
the Sun_ , which was about a young boy.[3] Spielberg—who was later awarded the
[Distinguished Eagle Scout Award](/wiki/Distinguished_Eagle_Scout_Award
"Distinguished Eagle Scout Award")—had the idea of making Indiana a [Boy
Scout](/wiki/Boy_Scout "Boy Scout").[13] [Indiana's
mother](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_the_Indiana_Jones_series#Anna "List of
characters in the Indiana Jones series"), named Margaret in this version,
dismisses Indiana when he returns home with the Cross of Coronado, while his
father is on a long distance call. Walter Chandler of the Chandler Foundation
features, but is not the main villain; he plunges to his death in the tank.
Elsa introduces Indiana and Brody to a large Venetian family that knows Henry.
[Leni Riefenstahl](/wiki/Leni_Riefenstahl "Leni Riefenstahl") appears at the
Nazi rally in Berlin. Vogel is beheaded by the traps guarding the Grail. Kemal
tries to blow up the Grail Temple during a comic fight in which gunpowder is
repeatedly lit and extinguished. Elsa shoots Henry, then dies drinking from
the wrong Grail, and Indiana rescues his father from falling into the chasm
while grasping for the Grail. Boam's revision on March 1 showed Henry causing
the seagulls to strike the plane, and has Henry saving Indiana at the
end.[5][17]

Between an undated "Amblin" revision and a rewrite by [Tom
Stoppard](/wiki/Tom_Stoppard "Tom Stoppard") (under the pen name Barry Watson)
dated May 8, 1988,[5] further changes were made. Stoppard polished most of the
dialogue,[8][18] and created the "Panama Hat" character to link the prologue's
segments featuring the young and adult Indianas. The Venetian family is cut.
Kemal is renamed Kazim and now wants to protect the grail rather than find it.
Chandler is renamed Donovan. The scene of Brody being captured is added. Vogel
now dies in the tank, while Donovan shoots Henry and then drinks from the
false grail, and Elsa falls into the chasm. The Grail trials are expanded to
include the stone-stepping and leap of faith.[5][19]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Tabernas2.jpg/220px-
Tabernas2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tabernas2.jpg)

The tank chase was filmed in the [Tabernas Desert](/wiki/Tabernas_Desert
"Tabernas Desert") in Almería, Spain

[Principal photography](/wiki/Principal_photography "Principal photography")
began on May 16, 1988, in the [Tabernas Desert](/wiki/Tabernas_Desert
"Tabernas Desert") in [Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain")'s [Almería
province](/wiki/Almer%C3%ADa_\(province\) "Almería \(province\)"). Spielberg
originally had planned the chase to be a short sequence shot over two days,
but he drew up storyboards to make the scene an action-packed centerpiece.[4]
Thinking he would not surpass the truck chase from _Raiders of the Lost Ark_
(because the truck was much faster than the tank), he felt this sequence
should be more story-based and needed to show Indiana and Henry helping each
other. He later said he had more fun storyboarding the sequence than filming
it.[20] The [second unit](/wiki/Second_unit "Second unit") had begun filming
two weeks before.[11] After approximately ten days, the production moved to
[Bellas Artes](/wiki/Museo_de_Bellas_Artes_de_Sevilla "Museo de Bellas Artes
de Sevilla") to film the scenes set in the Sultan of Hatay's palace. [Cabo de
Gata-Níjar Natural Park](/wiki/Cabo_de_Gata-N%C3%ADjar_Natural_Park "Cabo de
Gata-Níjar Natural Park") was used for the road, tunnel and beach sequence in
which birds strike the plane. The shoot's Spanish portion wrapped on June 2,
1988, in [Guadix](/wiki/Guadix "Guadix"), [Granada](/wiki/Granada_\(province\)
"Granada \(province\)"), with filming of Brody's capture at İskenderun train
station.[11] The filmmakers built a mosque near the station for atmosphere,
rather than adding it as a visual effect.[20]

Filming for the castle interiors took place in the [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") from June 5 to 10, 1988, at
[Elstree Studios](/wiki/Elstree_Studios "Elstree Studios") in
[Borehamwood](/wiki/Borehamwood "Borehamwood"), [England](/wiki/England
"England"). On June 16 [Lawrence Hall, London](/wiki/Lawrence_Hall,_London
"Lawrence Hall, London"), was used for the airport interiors. Filming returned
to Elstree the next day to capture the motorcycle escape, continuing at the
studio for interior scenes until July 18. One day was spent at [North Weald
Airfield](/wiki/North_Weald_Airfield "North Weald Airfield") on June 29 to
film Indiana leaving for Venice.[11] Ford and Connery acted much of the
Zeppelin table conversation without trousers on because of the overheated
set.[21] Spielberg, Marshall and Kennedy interrupted the shoot to make a plea
to the [Parliament of the United
Kingdom](/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom "Parliament of the United
Kingdom") to support the economically "depressed" British studios. July 20–22
was spent filming the temple interiors. The temple set, which took six weeks
to build, was supported on 80 feet of hydraulics and ten
[gimbals](/wiki/Gimbal "Gimbal") for use during the earthquake scene.
Resetting between takes took twenty minutes while the hydraulics were put to
their starting positions and the cracks filled with plaster. The shot of the
Grail falling to the temple floor—causing the first crack to appear—was
attempted on the full-size set, but proved too difficult. Instead, crews built
a separate floor section that incorporated a pre-scored crack sealed with
plaster. It took several takes to throw the Grail from six feet onto the right
part of the crack.[20] July 25–26 was spent on night shoots at [Stowe
School](/wiki/Stowe_School "Stowe School"), [Stowe,
Buckinghamshire](/wiki/Stowe,_Buckinghamshire "Stowe, Buckinghamshire"), for
the Nazi rally.[11]

Filming resumed two days later at Elstree, where Spielberg swiftly filmed the
library, Portuguese freighter, and catacombs sequences.[11] The steamship
fight in the prologue's 1938 portion was filmed in three days on a sixty-by-
forty-feet deck built on gimbals at Elstree. A dozen dump tanks—each holding
three hundred imperial gallons (360 U.S. gallons; 3000 lb.) of water—were used
in the scene.[20] Henry's house was filmed at [Mill Hill](/wiki/Mill_Hill
"Mill Hill"), London. Indiana and Kazim's fight in Venice in front of a ship's
propeller was filmed in a water tank at Elstree. Spielberg used a [long focus
lens](/wiki/Long_focus_lens "Long focus lens") to make it appear the actors
were closer to the propeller than they really were.[11] Two days later, on
August 4, another portion of the boat chase using [Hacker
Craft](/wiki/Hacker_Craft "Hacker Craft") sport boats, was filmed at [Tilbury
Docks](/wiki/Port_of_Tilbury "Port of Tilbury") in [Essex](/wiki/Essex
"Essex").[11] The shot of the boats passing between two ships was achieved by
first cabling the ships off so they would be safe. The ships were moved
together while the boats passed between, close enough that one of the boats
scraped the sides of the ships. An empty speedboat containing dummies was
launched from a floating platform between the ships amid fire and smoke that
helped obscure the platform. The stunt was performed twice because the boat
landed too short of the camera in the first attempt.[20] The following day,
filming in England wrapped at the [Royal Masonic
School](/wiki/Royal_Masonic_School "Royal Masonic School") in
[Rickmansworth](/wiki/Rickmansworth "Rickmansworth"), which doubled for
Indiana's college (as it had in _Raiders of the Lost Ark_).[11]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Petra_Jordan_BW_21.JPG/170px-
Petra_Jordan_BW_21.JPG)](/wiki/File:Petra_Jordan_BW_21.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Petra_Jordan_BW_21.JPG "Enlarge")

[Al Khazneh](/wiki/Al_Khazneh "Al Khazneh") (The Treasury) at Petra, Jordan
was used for the entrance to the temple housing the Holy Grail

Shooting in Venice took place on August 8.[11] For scenes such as Indiana and
Brody greeting Elsa, shots of the boat chase, and Kazim telling Indiana where
his father is,[20] [Robert Watts](/wiki/Robert_Watts "Robert Watts") gained
control of the [Grand Canal](/wiki/Grand_Canal_\(Venice\) "Grand Canal
\(Venice\)") from 7 am to 1 pm, sealing off tourists for as long as possible.
Cinematographer [Douglas Slocombe](/wiki/Douglas_Slocombe "Douglas Slocombe")
positioned the camera to ensure no satellite dishes would be visible.[11] [San
Barnaba di Venezia](/wiki/San_Barnaba_di_Venezia "San Barnaba di Venezia")
served as the library's exterior.[4] The next day, filming moved to the
ancient city of [Petra](/wiki/Petra "Petra"), [Jordan](/wiki/Jordan "Jordan"),
where [Al Khazneh](/wiki/Al_Khazneh "Al Khazneh") (The Treasury) stood in for
the temple housing the Grail. The cast and crew became guests of [King
Hussein](/wiki/Hussein_of_Jordan "Hussein of Jordan") and [Queen
Noor](/wiki/Queen_Noor_of_Jordan "Queen Noor of Jordan"). The Treasury had
previously appeared in _[Sinbad and the Eye of the
Tiger](/wiki/Sinbad_and_the_Eye_of_the_Tiger "Sinbad and the Eye of the
Tiger")_. The main cast completed their scenes that week, after 63 days of
filming.[11]

The second unit filmed part of the prologue's 1912 segment from August 29 to
September 3. The main unit began two days later with the circus train sequence
at [Alamosa, Colorado](/wiki/Alamosa,_Colorado "Alamosa, Colorado"), on the
[Cumbres and Toltec Scenic Railroad](/wiki/Cumbres_and_Toltec_Scenic_Railroad
"Cumbres and Toltec Scenic Railroad"). They filmed at [Pagosa
Springs](/wiki/Pagosa_Springs,_Colorado "Pagosa Springs, Colorado") on
September 7, and then at [Cortez](/wiki/Cortez,_Colorado "Cortez, Colorado")
on September 10. From September 14 to 16, filming of Indiana falling into the
train carriages took place in Los Angeles. The production then moved to Utah's
[Arches National Park](/wiki/Arches_National_Park "Arches National Park") to
shoot more of the opening. A house in Antonito, Colorado was used for the
Jones family home.[22] The production had intended to film at [Mesa Verde
National Park](/wiki/Mesa_Verde_National_Park "Mesa Verde National Park"), but
[Native American](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native
Americans in the United States") representatives had religious objections to
its use.[20] When Spielberg and editor [Michael
Kahn](/wiki/Michael_Kahn_\(film_editor\) "Michael Kahn \(film editor\)")
viewed a [rough cut](/wiki/Rough_cut "Rough cut") of the film in late 1988,
they felt it suffered from a lack of action. The motorcycle chase was shot
during [post-production](/wiki/Post-production "Post-production") at [Mount
Tamalpais](/wiki/Mount_Tamalpais "Mount Tamalpais") and
[Fairfax](/wiki/Fairfax,_California "Fairfax, California") near [Skywalker
Ranch](/wiki/Skywalker_Ranch "Skywalker Ranch"). The closing shot of Indiana,
Henry, Sallah and Brody riding into the sunset was filmed in
[Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas") in early 1989.[11][9]

###
Design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Design")]

Mechanical effects supervisor [George
Gibbs](/wiki/George_Gibbs_\(special_effects_artist\) "George Gibbs \(special
effects artist\)") said the film was the most difficult one of his career.[20]
He visited a museum to negotiate renting a small French [World War I
tank](/wiki/Tanks_in_World_War_I "Tanks in World War I"), but decided he
wanted to make one.[11] The tank was based on the [Tank Mark
VIII](/wiki/Tank_Mark_VIII "Tank Mark VIII"), which was 36 feet (11 m) long
and weighed 28 short tons (25 t). Gibbs built the tank over the framework of a
28-short-ton (25 t) [excavator](/wiki/Excavator "Excavator") and added
7-short-ton (6.4 t) [tracks](/wiki/Continuous_track "Continuous track") that
were driven by two automatic [hydraulic pumps](/wiki/Hydraulic_pump "Hydraulic
pump"), each connected to a [Range Rover](/wiki/Range_Rover "Range Rover") [V8
engine](/wiki/Rover_V8_engine "Rover V8 engine"). Gibbs built the tank from
steel rather than aluminum or fiberglass because it would allow the
realistically [suspensionless](/wiki/Suspension_\(vehicle\) "Suspension
\(vehicle\)") vehicle to endure the rocky surfaces. Unlike its historical
counterpart, which had only the two side guns, the tank had a turret gun added
as well. It took four months to build and was transported to Almería on a
[Short Belfast](/wiki/Short_Belfast "Short Belfast") plane and then a low
loader truck.[20]

The tank broke down twice. The [distributor](/wiki/Distributor
"Distributor")'s rotor arm broke and a replacement had to be sourced from
[Madrid](/wiki/Madrid "Madrid"). Then two of the device's valves used to cool
the oil exploded, due to [solder](/wiki/Solder "Solder") melting and mixing
with the oil. It was very hot in the tank, despite the installation of ten
fans, and the lack of suspension meant the driver was unable to stop shaking
during filming breaks.[20] The tank only moved at 10 to 12 miles per hour (16
to 19 km/h), which [Vic Armstrong](/wiki/Vic_Armstrong "Vic Armstrong") said
made it difficult to film Indiana riding a horse against the tank while making
it appear faster.[11] A smaller section of the tank's top made from aluminum
and which used rubber tracks was used for close-ups. It was built from a
searchlight trailer, weighed eight tons, and was towed by a four-wheel drive
truck. It had safety nets on each end to prevent injury to those falling
off.[20] A quarter-scale model by Gibbs was driven over a 50-foot (15 m) cliff
on location; [Industrial Light & Magic](/wiki/Industrial_Light_%26_Magic
"Industrial Light & Magic") created further shots of the tank's destruction
with models and miniatures.[23]

[Michael Lantieri](/wiki/Michael_Lantieri "Michael Lantieri"), mechanical
effects supervisor for the 1912 scenes, noted the difficulty in shooting the
train sequence. "You can't just stop a train," he said, "If it misses its
mark, it takes blocks and blocks to stop it and back up." Lantieri hid handles
for the actors and stuntmen to grab onto when leaping from carriage to
carriage. The carriage interiors shot at [Universal Studios
Hollywood](/wiki/Universal_Studios_Hollywood "Universal Studios Hollywood")
were built on tubes that inflated and deflated to create a rocking motion.[20]
For the close-up of the rhinoceros that strikes at (and misses) Indiana, a
foam and fiberglass animatronic was made in London. When Spielberg decided he
wanted it to move, the prop was sent to [John Carl
Buechler](/wiki/John_Carl_Buechler "John Carl Buechler") in Los Angeles, who
resculpted it over three days to blink, snarl, snort and wiggle its ears. The
giraffes were also created in London. Because steam locomotives are very loud,
Lantieri's crew would respond to [first assistant
director](/wiki/Assistant_director#Sub-roles "Assistant director") [David
Tomblin](/wiki/David_Tomblin "David Tomblin")'s radioed directions by making
the giraffes nod or shake their heads to his questions, which amused the
crew.[23] For the villains' cars, Lantieri selected a 1914 [Ford Model
T](/wiki/Ford_Model_T "Ford Model T"), a 1919 [Ford Model
T](/wiki/Ford_Model_T "Ford Model T") truck and a 1916
[Saxon](/wiki/Saxon_\(automobile\) "Saxon \(automobile\)") Model 14, fitting
each with a [Ford Pinto](/wiki/Ford_Pinto "Ford Pinto") [V6
engine](/wiki/V6_engine "V6 engine"). Sacks of dust were hung under the cars
to create a dustier environment.[20]

Spielberg used doves for the seagulls that Henry scares into striking the
German plane because the real gulls used in the first take did not fly.[4] In
December 1988, Lucasfilm ordered 1,000 disease-free gray rats for the
catacombs scenes from the company that supplied the snakes and bugs for the
previous films. Within five months, 5,000 rats had been bred for the
sequence;[4] 1,000 mechanical rats stood in for those that were set on fire.
Several thousand snakes of five breeds—including a [boa
constrictor](/wiki/Boa_constrictor "Boa constrictor")—were used for the train
scene, in addition to rubber ones onto which Phoenix could fall. The snakes
would slither from their crates, requiring the crew to dig through sawdust
after filming to find and return them. Two lions were used, which became
nervous because of the rocking motion and flickering lights.[20]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/90/LastCrusadeTank.jpg/220px-
LastCrusadeTank.jpg)](/wiki/File:LastCrusadeTank.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:LastCrusadeTank.jpg "Enlarge")

Composite photograph of the tank on location

Costume designer [Anthony Powell](/wiki/Anthony_Powell_\(designer\) "Anthony
Powell \(designer\)") found it a challenge to create Connery's costume because
the script required the character to wear the same clothes throughout. Powell
thought about his own grandfather and incorporated
[tweed](/wiki/Tweed_\(cloth\) "Tweed \(cloth\)") suits and fishing hats.
Powell felt it necessary for Henry to wear glasses, but did not want to hide
Connery's eyes, so chose rimless ones. He could not find any suitable, so he
had them specially made. The Nazi costumes were genuine and were found in
Eastern Europe by Powell's co-designer Joanna Johnston, to whom he gave
research pictures and drawings for reference.[11] The motorcycles used in the
chase from the castle were a mixed bag: the scout model with sidecar in which
Indy and Henry escape was an original [Dnepr](/wiki/Dnepr_\(motorcycle\)
"Dnepr \(motorcycle\)"), complete with machine gun
[pintle](/wiki/Pintle_mount#Pintle "Pintle mount") on the sidecar, while the
pursuing vehicles were more modern machines dressed up with equipment and
logos to make them resemble German army models. Gibbs used Swiss [Pilatus
P-2](/wiki/Pilatus_P-2 "Pilatus P-2") army training planes standing in for
[Messerschmitt Bf-109s](/wiki/Messerschmitt_Bf-109 "Messerschmitt Bf-109"). He
built a device based on an [internal combustion
engine](/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine "Internal combustion engine") to
simulate gunfire, which was safer and less expensive than firing
[blanks](/wiki/Blank_\(cartridge\) "Blank \(cartridge\)").[23] Baking soda was
applied to Connery to create Henry's bullet wound. Vinegar was applied to
create the foaming effect as the water from the Grail washes it away.[23] At
least one reproduction [Kubelwagen](/wiki/Kubelwagen "Kubelwagen") was used
during filming despite the film being set two years prior to manufacture of
said vehicles.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

###
Effects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Effects")]

[Industrial Light & Magic](/wiki/Industrial_Light_%26_Magic "Industrial Light
& Magic") (ILM) built an eight-foot foam model of the Zeppelin to complement
shots of Ford and Connery climbing into the biplane. A biplane model with a
two-foot wingspan was used for the shot of the biplane detaching. [Stop
motion](/wiki/Stop_motion "Stop motion") animation was used for the shot of
the German fighter's wings breaking off as it crashes through the tunnel. The
tunnel was a 210 feet model that occupied 14 of ILM's parking spaces for two
months. It was built in eight-foot sections, with hinges allowing each section
to be opened to film through. Ford and Connery were filmed against
[bluescreen](/wiki/Chroma_key "Chroma key"); the sequence required their car
to have a dirty windscreen, but to make the integration easier this was
removed and later [composited](/wiki/Compositing "Compositing") into the shot.
Dust and shadows were animated onto shots of the plane miniature to make it
appear as if it disturbed rocks and dirt before it exploded. Several hundred
[tim-birds](/wiki/Tim-bird "Tim-bird") were used in the background shots of
the seagulls striking the other plane; for the closer shots, ILM dropped
feather-coated crosses onto the camera. These only looked convincing because
the scene's quick cuts merely required shapes that suggested gulls.[23] ILM's
[Wes Takahashi](/wiki/Wes_Takahashi "Wes Takahashi") supervised the film's
effects sequences.[24]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d2/Leapoffaith.jpg/220px-
Leapoffaith.jpg)](/wiki/File:Leapoffaith.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Leapoffaith.jpg "Enlarge")

Indiana discovers a bridge hidden by [camouflage](/wiki/Camouflage
"Camouflage"). Ford was filmed in front of a bluescreen for the scene, which
was completed by a model of the bridge filmed against a matte painting

Spielberg devised the three trials that guard the Grail.[3] For the first, the
blades under which Indiana ducks like a penitent man were a mix of practical
and miniature blades created by Gibbs and ILM. For the second trial, in which
Indiana spells "[Iehova](/wiki/Jehovah "Jehovah")" on stable stepping stones,
it was intended to have a tarantula crawl up Indiana after he mistakenly steps
on "J". This was filmed and deemed unsatisfactory, so ILM filmed a stuntman
hanging through a hole that appears in the floor, 30 feet above a cavern. As
this was dark, it did not matter that the matte painting and models were
rushed late in production. The third trial, the leap of faith that Indiana
makes over an apparently impassable ravine after discovering a bridge hidden
by [forced perspective](/wiki/Forced_perspective "Forced perspective"), was
created with a model bridge and painted backgrounds. This was cheaper than
building a full-size set. A puppet of Ford was used to create a shadow on the
9-foot-tall (2.7 m) by 13-foot-wide (4.0 m) model because Ford had filmed the
scene against bluescreen, which did not incorporate the shaft of light from
the entrance.[23]

Spielberg wanted Donovan's death shown in one shot, so it would not look like
an actor having makeup applied between takes. Inflatable pads were applied to
[Julian Glover](/wiki/Julian_Glover "Julian Glover")'s forehead and cheeks
that made his eyes seem to recede during the character's initial
decomposition, as well as a mechanical wig that grew his hair. The shot of
Donovan's death was created over three months by [morphing](/wiki/Morphing
"Morphing") together three puppets of Donovan in separate stages of decay, a
technique ILM mastered on _[Willow](/wiki/Willow_\(film\) "Willow \(film\)")_
(1988).[21] A fourth puppet was used for the decaying clothes, because the
puppet's torso mechanics had been exposed. Complications arose because [Alison
Doody](/wiki/Alison_Doody "Alison Doody")'s double had not been filmed for the
scene's latter two elements, so the background and hair from the first shot
had to be used throughout, with the other faces [mapped](/wiki/Texture_mapping
"Texture mapping") over it. Donovan's skeleton was hung on wires like a
[marionette](/wiki/Marionette "Marionette"); it required several takes to film
it crashing against the wall because not all the pieces released upon
impact.[23]

[Ben Burtt](/wiki/Ben_Burtt "Ben Burtt") designed the sound effects. He
recorded chickens for the sounds of the rats,[11] and digitally manipulated
the noise made by a Styrofoam cup for the castle fire. He rode in a biplane to
record the sounds for the dogfight sequence, and visited the demolition of a
[wind turbine](/wiki/Wind_turbine "Wind turbine") for the plane crashes.[23]
Burtt wanted an echoing gunshot for Donovan wounding Henry, so he fired a
[.357 Magnum](/wiki/.357_Magnum ".357 Magnum") in [Skywalker
Ranch](/wiki/Skywalker_Ranch "Skywalker Ranch")'s underground car park, just
as Lucas drove in.[11] A rubber balloon was used for the earthquake tremors at
the temple.[25] The film was released in selected theaters in the 70 mm Full-
Field Sound format, which allowed sounds to not only move from side to side,
but also from the theater's [front to its rear](/wiki/Quadraphonic_sound
"Quadraphonic sound").[23]

[Matte paintings](/wiki/Matte_painting "Matte painting") of the Austrian
castle and German airport were based on real buildings; the Austrian castle
was a small West German castle that was made to look larger. Rain was created
by filming granulated [Borax](/wiki/Borax "Borax") soap against black at high
speed. It was only lightly [double
exposed](/wiki/Multiple_exposure#Double_exposure "Multiple exposure") into the
shots so it would not resemble snow. The lightning was animated. The airport
used was at San Francisco's [Treasure
Island](/wiki/Treasure_Island_\(California\) "Treasure Island
\(California\)"), which already had appropriate [art deco](/wiki/Art_deco "Art
deco") architecture. ILM added a control tower, Nazi banners, vintage
automobiles and a sign stating "Berlin Flughafen". The establishing shot of
the Hatayan city at dusk was created by filming silhouetted cutouts that were
backlit and obscured by smoke. Matte paintings were used for the sky and to
give the appearance of [fill light](/wiki/Fill_light "Fill light") in the
shadows and [rim light](/wiki/Backlighting_\(lighting_design\) "Backlighting
\(lighting design\)") on the edges of the buildings.[23]

##
Themes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Themes")]

A son's relationship with his estranged father is a common theme in
Spielberg's films, including _[E.T. the Extra-
Terrestrial](/wiki/E.T._the_Extra-Terrestrial "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial")_
and _[Hook](/wiki/Hook_\(film\) "Hook \(film\)")_.[7]

The film's exploration of fathers and sons coupled with its use of religious
imagery is comparable to two other 1989 films, _[Star Trek V: The Final
Frontier](/wiki/Star_Trek_V:_The_Final_Frontier "Star Trek V: The Final
Frontier")_ and _[Field of Dreams](/wiki/Field_of_Dreams "Field of Dreams")_.
Writing for _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York
Times")_ , Caryn James felt the combination in these films reflected [New
Age](/wiki/New_Age "New Age") concerns, where the worship of God was equated
to searching for fathers. James felt that neither Indiana or his father is
preoccupied with finding the Grail or defeating the evil Nazis, but that,
rather, both seek professional respect for one another in their [boys'
own](/wiki/Boy%27s_Own_Paper "Boy's Own Paper") adventure. James contrasted
the temple's biblically epic destruction with the more effective and quiet
conversation between the Joneses at the film's end. James noted that Indiana's
mother does not appear in the prologue, being portrayed as already having died
before the film's events began.[26]

## Cultural
references[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Cultural references")]

The 1912 prologue refers to events in the lives of Indiana's creators. When
Indiana cracks the bullwhip to defend himself against a lion, he accidentally
lashes and scars his chin. Ford gained this scar in a car accident as a young
man.[4] Indiana taking his nickname from his pet [Alaskan
Malamute](/wiki/Alaskan_Malamute "Alaskan Malamute") is a reference to the
character being named after Lucas's dog.[21] The train carriage Indiana enters
is named "Doctor Fantasy's Magic Caboose", which was the name producer [Frank
Marshall](/wiki/Frank_Marshall_\(film_producer\) "Frank Marshall \(film
producer\)") used when performing magic tricks. Spielberg suggested the idea,
Marshall came up with the false-bottomed box through which Indiana
escapes,[27] and production designer Elliott Scott suggested the trick be done
in a single, uninterrupted shot.[20] Spielberg intended the shot of Henry with
his umbrella—after he causes the bird strike on the German plane—to evoke
_[Ryan's Daughter](/wiki/Ryan%27s_Daughter "Ryan's Daughter")_.[21]

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Release")]

###
Marketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Marketing")]

See also: [Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade
(soundtrack)](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade_\(soundtrack\) "Indiana
Jones and the Last Crusade \(soundtrack\)")

The film's [teaser trailer](/wiki/Teaser_trailer "Teaser trailer") debuted in
November 1988 with _[Scrooged](/wiki/Scrooged "Scrooged")_ and _[The Naked
Gun](/wiki/The_Naked_Gun:_From_the_Files_of_Police_Squad! "The Naked Gun: From
the Files of Police Squad!")_.[28] Rob MacGregor wrote the [tie-in](/wiki/Tie-
in "Tie-in") novelization that was released in June 1989;[29] it sold enough
copies to be included on the [_New York Times_ Best Seller
list](/wiki/New_York_Times_Best_Seller_list "New York Times Best Seller
list").[30] MacGregor went on to write the first six [_Indiana Jones_ prequel
novels](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_\(franchise\)#Adult_novels "Indiana Jones
\(franchise\)") during the 1990s. Following the film's release, Ford donated
Indiana's fedora and jacket to the [Smithsonian
Institution](/wiki/Smithsonian_Institution "Smithsonian Institution")'s
[National Museum of American
History](/wiki/National_Museum_of_American_History "National Museum of
American History").[31]

No toys were made to promote the film; Indiana Jones "never happened on the
toy level", said Larry Carlat, senior editor of the journal _Children 's
Business_. Rather, Lucasfilm promoted Indiana as a lifestyle symbol, selling
tie-in fedoras, shirts, jackets and watches.[32] [Two video
games](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade_\(video_game\) "Indiana Jones
and the Last Crusade \(video game\)") based on the film were released by
[LucasArts](/wiki/LucasArts "LucasArts") in 1989: _[Indiana Jones and the Last
Crusade: The Graphic
Adventure](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade:_The_Graphic_Adventure
"Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade: The Graphic Adventure")_ and _[Indiana
Jones and the Last Crusade: The Action
Game](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade:_The_Action_Game "Indiana Jones
and the Last Crusade: The Action Game")_. [A third
game](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade_\(1991_video_game\) "Indiana
Jones and the Last Crusade \(1991 video game\)") was produced by
[Taito](/wiki/Taito "Taito") and released in 1991 for the [Nintendo
Entertainment System](/wiki/Nintendo_Entertainment_System "Nintendo
Entertainment System"). [Ryder Windham](/wiki/Ryder_Windham "Ryder Windham")
wrote another novelization, released in April 2008 by
[Scholastic](/wiki/Scholastic_Corporation "Scholastic Corporation"), to
coincide with the release of _[Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal
Skull](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Kingdom_of_the_Crystal_Skull "Indiana Jones
and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull")_. [Hasbro](/wiki/Hasbro "Hasbro")
released toys based on _The Last Crusade_ in July 2008.[33]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Box office")]

The film was released in North America on May 24, 1989, in 2,327 theaters,
earning $29,355,021 in its opening weekend.[34] This was the third-highest
opening weekend of 1989, behind _[Ghostbusters II](/wiki/Ghostbusters_II
"Ghostbusters II")_ and _[Batman](/wiki/Batman_\(1989_film\) "Batman \(1989
film\)")_.[35] Its opening day gross of $11,181,429 was the first time a film
had made over $10 million on its first day. It broke the record for the best
six-day performance, with almost $47 million, added another record with $77
million after twelve days, and $100 million in nineteen days. It grossed
$195.7 million by the end of the year and $475 million worldwide by March
1990.[11] In France, the film broke a record by selling a million admissions
within two and a half weeks.[31]

The film eventually grossed $197,171,806 in North America and $277 million
internationally, for a worldwide total of $474,171,806.[34] At the time of its
release, the film was the 11th highest-grossing film of all time.[34] Despite
competition from _Batman_ , _The Last Crusade_ became the highest-grossing
film worldwide in 1989.[36] In North America, _Batman_ took top position.[35]
Behind _[Kingdom of the Crystal
Skull](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Kingdom_of_the_Crystal_Skull "Indiana Jones
and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull")_ and _Raiders_ , _The Last Crusade_ is
the third-highest grossing [Indiana Jones](/wiki/Indiana_Jones "Indiana
Jones") film in North America, though it is also behind _Temple of Doom_ when
adjusting for inflation.[37] [Box Office Mojo](/wiki/Box_Office_Mojo "Box
Office Mojo") estimates that the film sold over 49 million tickets in North
America.[38]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Critical response")]

The film opened to mostly positive reviews. It was panned by [Andrew
Sarris](/wiki/Andrew_Sarris "Andrew Sarris") in _[The New York
Observer](/wiki/The_New_York_Observer "The New York Observer")_ , [David
Denby](/wiki/David_Denby_\(film_critic\) "David Denby \(film critic\)") in
_[New York](/wiki/New_York_\(magazine\) "New York \(magazine\)")_ magazine,
[Stanley Kauffmann](/wiki/Stanley_Kauffmann "Stanley Kauffmann") in _[The New
Republic](/wiki/The_New_Republic "The New Republic")_ and Georgia Brown in
_[The Village Voice](/wiki/The_Village_Voice "The Village Voice")_.[11]
[Jonathan Rosenbaum](/wiki/Jonathan_Rosenbaum "Jonathan Rosenbaum") of the
_[Chicago Reader](/wiki/Chicago_Reader "Chicago Reader")_ called the film
"soulless".[39] _[The Washington Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The
Washington Post")_ reviewed the film twice; Hal Hinson's review on the day of
the film's release was negative, describing it as "nearly all chases and dull
exposition". Although he praised Ford and Connery, he felt the film's
exploration of Indiana's character took away his mystery and that Spielberg
should not have tried to mature his storytelling.[40] Two days later, [Desson
Thomson](/wiki/Desson_Thomson "Desson Thomson") published a positive review
praising the film's adventure and action, as well as the father–son
relationship's thematic depth.[41] [Joseph
McBride](/wiki/Joseph_McBride_\(writer\) "Joseph McBride \(writer\)") of
_[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)")_ observed the
"Cartoonlike Nazi villains of _Raiders_ have been replaced by more genuinely
frightening Nazis led by Julian Glover and Michael Byrne," and found the
moment where Indiana meets Hitler "chilling".[42] In his biography of
Spielberg, McBride added the film was less "racist" than its predecessors.[7]

[Peter Travers](/wiki/Peter_Travers "Peter Travers") of _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone_\(magazine\) "Rolling Stone \(magazine\)")_ said
the film was "the wildest and wittiest Indy of them all". [Richard
Corliss](/wiki/Richard_Corliss "Richard Corliss") of
_[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time \(magazine\)")_ and [David
Ansen](/wiki/David_Ansen "David Ansen") of _[Newsweek](/wiki/Newsweek
"Newsweek")_ praised it, as did [Vincent Canby](/wiki/Vincent_Canby "Vincent
Canby") of _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York
Times")_.[11] "Though it seems to have the manner of some magically
reconstituted B-movie of an earlier era, _The Last Crusade_ is an endearing
original," Canby wrote, deeming the revelation Indiana had a father he was not
proud of to be a "comic surprise". Canby believed that while the film did not
match the previous two in its pacing, it still had "hilariously off-the-wall
sequences" such as the circus train chase. He also said that Spielberg was
maturing by focusing on the father–son relationship,[43] a call echoed by
McBride in _Variety_.[42] [Roger Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert")
praised the scene depicting Indiana as a [Boy Scout](/wiki/Boy_Scout "Boy
Scout") with the Cross of Coronado; he compared it to the "style of
illustration that appeared in the boys' adventure magazines of the 1940s",
saying that Spielberg "must have been paging through his old issues of _[Boys'
Life](/wiki/Boys%27_Life "Boys' Life")_ magazine... the feeling that you can
stumble over astounding adventures just by going on a hike with your Scout
troop. Spielberg lights the scene in the strong, basic colors of old pulp
magazines."[44] _[The Hollywood Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The
Hollywood Reporter")_ felt Connery and Ford deserved Academy Award
nominations.[11]

The film was evaluated positively after its release. Internet reviewer [James
Berardinelli](/wiki/James_Berardinelli "James Berardinelli") wrote that while
the film did not reach the heights of _Raiders of the Lost Ark_ , it
"[avoided] the lows of _The Temple of Doom_. A fitting end to the original
trilogy, _Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade_ captures some of the sense of
fun that infused the first movie while using the addition of Sean Connery to
up the comedic ante and provide a father/son dynamic."[45] Neil Smith of the
[BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC") praised the action, but said the drama and comedy
between the Joneses was more memorable. He noted, "The emphasis on the Jones
boys means Julian Glover's venal villain and Alison Doody's treacherous beauty
are sidelined, while the climax [becomes] one booby-trapped tomb too
many."[46] Based on 55 reviews listed by _[Rotten
Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes")_ , 88% of critics praised
the film, giving it an [average](/wiki/Weighted_mean "Weighted mean") score of
8/10.[47] _[Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic")_ calculated an average
rating of 65/100, based on 14 reviews.[48]

###
Influence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Influence")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/SeanConneryJune08.jpg/170px-
SeanConneryJune08.jpg)](/wiki/File:SeanConneryJune08.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:SeanConneryJune08.jpg "Enlarge")

[Sean Connery](/wiki/Sean_Connery "Sean Connery") received Golden Globe and
BAFTA nominations for his performance

The film won the [Academy Award for Best Sound
Editing](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Sound_Editing "Academy Award for Best
Sound Editing"); it also received nominations for [Best Original
Score](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score "Academy Award for Best
Original Score") and [Best Sound](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Sound "Academy
Award for Best Sound") ([Ben Burtt](/wiki/Ben_Burtt "Ben Burtt"), [Gary
Summers](/wiki/Gary_Summers "Gary Summers"), [Shawn
Murphy](/wiki/Shawn_Murphy_\(sound_engineer\) "Shawn Murphy \(sound
engineer\)") and [Tony Dawe](/wiki/Tony_Dawe "Tony Dawe")), but lost to _[The
Little Mermaid](/wiki/The_Little_Mermaid_\(1989_film\) "The Little Mermaid
\(1989 film\)")_ and _[Glory](/wiki/Glory_\(1989_film\) "Glory \(1989
film\)")_ respectively.[49] Sean Connery received a [Golden Globe
Award](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award "Golden Globe Award") nomination for [Best
Supporting
Actor](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actor_%E2%80%93_Motion_Picture
"Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor – Motion Picture").[50] Connery
and the visual and sound effects teams were also nominated at the [43rd
British Academy Film Awards](/wiki/43rd_British_Academy_Film_Awards "43rd
British Academy Film Awards").[51] The film won the 1990 [Hugo Award for Best
Dramatic Presentation](/wiki/Hugo_Award_for_Best_Dramatic_Presentation "Hugo
Award for Best Dramatic Presentation"),[52] and was nominated for Best Motion
Picture Drama at the [Young Artist Awards](/wiki/Young_Artist_Award "Young
Artist Award").[53] John Williams' score won a
[BMI](/wiki/Broadcast_Music_Incorporated "Broadcast Music Incorporated")
Award, and was nominated for a [Grammy Award](/wiki/Grammy_Award "Grammy
Award").[54]

The prologue depicting Indiana in his youth inspired Lucas to create _[The
Young Indiana Jones Chronicles](/wiki/The_Young_Indiana_Jones_Chronicles "The
Young Indiana Jones Chronicles")_ television series, which featured [Sean
Patrick Flanery](/wiki/Sean_Patrick_Flanery "Sean Patrick Flanery") as the
young adult Indiana and [Corey Carrier](/wiki/Corey_Carrier "Corey Carrier")
as the 8- to 10-year-old Indiana.[9] The 13-year-old incarnation played by
Phoenix in the film was the focus of a _Young Indiana Jones_ series of young
adult novels that began in 1990;[55] by the ninth novel, the series had become
a tie-in to the television show.[56] German author [Wolfgang
Hohlbein](/wiki/Wolfgang_Hohlbein "Wolfgang Hohlbein") revisited the 1912
prologue in one of his novels, in which Indiana encounters the lead grave
robber—whom Hohlbein christens Jake—in 1943.[57] The film's ending begins the
1995 comic series _[Indiana Jones and the Spear of
Destiny](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Spear_of_Destiny "Indiana Jones and the
Spear of Destiny")_ , which moves forward to depict Indiana and his father
searching for the [Holy Lance](/wiki/Holy_Lance "Holy Lance") in Ireland in
1945.[58] Spielberg intended to have Connery cameo as Henry in _Kingdom of the
Crystal Skull_ (2008), but Connery turned it down as he had retired.[59]

[![Two small shops offering Coca-Cola products and other soft drinks in glass-
fronted refrigerated containers. In the middle is an umbrella with the Pepsi
logo. Above them are signs referencing Indiana Jones and depicting him. A
small group of people is walking past and in front of them on the
right](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Shops_near_Petra%2C_Jordan%2C_with_Indiana_Jones_signs.jpg/220px-
Shops_near_Petra%2C_Jordan%2C_with_Indiana_Jones_signs.jpg)](/wiki/File:Shops_near_Petra,_Jordan,_with_Indiana_Jones_signs.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Shops_near_Petra,_Jordan,_with_Indiana_Jones_signs.jpg
"Enlarge")

Shops using imagery from this film and the fourth film to promote themselves
outside the entrance to Petra

Petra's use for the movie's climactic scenes greatly contributed to its
popularity as an international tourist destination. Before the film's release,
only a few thousand visitors per year made the trip; since then it has grown
to almost a million annually.[60] Shops and hotels near the site play up the
connection, and it is mentioned prominently in itineraries of locations used
in the film series.[61] Jordan's tourism board mentions the connection on its
website.[62] In 2012 the satirical news site [The Pan-Arabia
Enquirer](/wiki/The_Pan-Arabia_Enquirer "The Pan-Arabia Enquirer") ran a mock
story claiming that the board had officially renamed Petra "That Place from
_Indiana Jones_ " to reflect how the world more commonly refers to it.[63]
